text:
(Family Features) Homeowners still have time to take advantage of a federal tax credit of up to 30% of the cost of eligible energy-efficient home improvements. The Energy Efficient Home Improvement Credit (also known as the 25C tax credit) can help offset the expense of updating or upgrading major home systems while also lowering energy consumption.

Understanding the 25C Tax Credit

Homeowners in the United States may be eligible when they install qualifying energy-efficient equipment in their primary residence such as all-climate electric heat pumps, insulation, windows and other improvements. The credit is subject to some limitations; for example, a homeowner can only claim up to $2,000 per year for a heat pump. The installation must be an addition or improvement to an existing home, not a new home, and can be used in combination with other tax credits or incentives such as local, utility and federal incentives and IRA programs.

The current version of this tax credit was implemented Jan. 1, 2023, and expires Dec. 31, 2025. In addition, rising energy costs and potential regulatory changes in 2026, such as updated guidelines on refrigerant, make late 2025 a strategic time to upgrade systems.

Smart Ways to Use the Tax Credit

Generally, energy-saving upgrades are some of the most common home improvement projects because they enhance the home's overall function while increasing the potential for cost savings on energy bills.

Some qualifying upgrades do double-duty by enhancing the home's curb appeal while reducing energy requirements. Common examples include windows, skylights and exterior doors.

Insulation and air sealing materials such as caulk and weatherstripping are also common choices, especially in older homes where insulation may be below current standards and settling has created gaps for air leaks.

Another common selection for homeowners looking to take advantage of the 25C tax credit is climate control systems, and an increasing number are turning to all-climate, all-electric heat pumps. One major reason is their high performance when it comes to energy efficiency. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, today's heat pumps can reduce electricity use for heating by 65% compared to electric resistance heating. In fact, Mitsubishi Electric all-climate, all-electric heat pumps have an efficiency rating at 260-490% compared to traditional systems at or below 100%.

In addition to their proven track record, contrary to a popular misconception that all-climate heat pumps are only for milder regions, the systems can operate quite effectively in both high heat and extreme cold. As a result, they provide homeowners with greater comfort and control of their indoor climate.

Take Steps to Beat the Deadline

If you're a homeowner planning to make upgrades and claim 25C tax credits, now is the ideal time to get your project underway.

Choose qualifying equipment. While some brands' complete product lines meet the qualification criteria, others do not. Do your homework to ensure the model you're installing is eligible for the credit. Your salesperson may be able to provide information, or you can visit the manufacturer website or contact the manufacturer directly for details.

Work with a certified contractor. Many reputable brands, including Mitsubishi Electric, offer a contractor network with highly skilled, knowledgeable and reputable installers.

Save your receipts to file. When you prepare your 2025 tax forms, you'll need to complete IRS Form 5695. Specifically, you will need to provide the manufacturer's pin number and other details about your purchase, including proof of purchase.

Find more tips to get started on a tax credit home upgrade project at mitsubishicomfort.com/inflation-reduction-act.

name: Indiana Environment
title: Has climate policy peaked? The rise and fall of a political cause - The Mandarin
authors: David Stadelmann, Benno Torgler, Melissa Coade, Ehsan Noroozinejad Farsangi, Greg Morrison, Bernard Keane, www.themandarin.com.au
description:
Such framing may generate headlines but risks undermining credibility and the international collaboration that effective climate policy would require.
Two questions follow: how climate policy rose to public prominence, and why doubts are now growing.
How climate policy rose to the top Until recently, climate protection dominated public discourse, around the world and particularly in Europe.
Thus, climate protection became a business and climate change offered endless opportunities to spend, regulate, and posture, with limited accountability for results.
But the politics of climate change — often marked by apocalyptic rhetoric, moral posturing, and costly symbolism — appears to have peaked.
text:
Australia has long been a proving ground for climate policy. Governments have announced ambitious targets, introduced complex regulatory schemes, and committed substantial subsidies to renewable energy. Outcomes, however, are mixed. Australia remains one of the world’s largest coal exporters. Although coal-fired generation is declining, the pace of the transition to wind, solar, and storage has been slower than anticipated, and the rollout of electricity generation transmission infrastructure is struggling to meet the 2030 target.

Debates intensified with the release of the National Climate Risk Assessment in 2025, presented as a sober appraisal of future risks. However, critics argued that the report relies on implausible scenarios of runaway coal use and global population growth, citing disaster cost projections attributed to climate change, even though an underlying review links rising losses primarily to increased population and property exposure rather than Australian CO₂ emissions. Such framing may generate headlines but risks undermining credibility and the international collaboration that effective climate policy would require.

Climate protection is the textbook case of a global public good: non-rivalry and non-excludability create strong incentives to free ride, leading to suboptimal collective outcomes. Unilateral Australian policies and actions have negligible direct effects on global temperatures; their value rests largely on demonstration, technology development, and diplomatic leverage rather than on measurable climate impacts per se. Countries and individuals who cut emissions bear the costs themselves, while the benefits are distributed worldwide. The incentives for any one country to act independently and substantially are therefore weak. Citizens care less about the global average temperature than about the local consequences — what they experience in their own environment.

Although international agreements could, in theory, solve this dilemma, in practice, they have dismally failed. Many signatory states are authoritarian, uninterested in constitutional principles and in the well-being of their own and other citizens. It was never credible that they would implement costly climate treaties for the sake of humanity’s future. Even more democratic countries retreat when the domestic costs bite, as the United States did when it exited the Paris Agreement under President Trump.

Behavioural and political economy considerations

There is evidence that “peak climate policy” may already have passed in many jurisdictions, and Australia may not be an exception. A behavioural economics and political economy lens helps explain why enthusiasm is cooling after years of moralised rhetoric about existential risk. Governments and voters now confront high fiscal costs, limited near-term climate benefits, and costly economic distortions created by complex policy instruments. As competing priorities — defence, pensions, infrastructure — press on limited budgets, grand narratives are giving way to more modest, pragmatic debate. Two questions follow: how climate policy rose to public prominence, and why doubts are now growing.

How climate policy rose to the top

Until recently, climate protection dominated public discourse, around the world and particularly in Europe. National politicians and representatives of the United Nations warned of an “existential threat” and “the greatest challenge in human history”. Yet, despite all the warnings and massive climate protests, fossil fuel use, global greenhouse gas emissions, and average temperatures continue to rise. By contrast, climate protests have dwindled if not fully disappeared; only media attention to “climate catastrophes” has not yet waned. In the 1990s, it seemed unlikely that climate protection would become a guiding political theme. Reducing CO₂ emissions and other greenhouse gases imposes immediate costs, while the benefits are very distant and uncertain. Politics and society generally prefer the opposite: benefits first, costs later. Despite these obstacles, climate protection became a dominant political cause, influencing elections and mobilising the streets. Modern politics, in combination with behavioural economics, helps explain why: the harder a problem is to solve and the longer it persists, the more it lends itself to being a political and moral topic. Thus, climate protection became a business and climate change offered endless opportunities to spend, regulate, and posture, with limited accountability for results. Six mechanisms were central.

1. Expressive behaviour. Because one nation’s contribution to emissions hardly matters for climate change, the effectiveness of its emissions reduction policies is almost irrelevant. Public discourse thus revolved not around efficiency but around climate change as a moral issue. Governments pledged long-term “net zero” targets decades away, while the true costs would fall on future administrations. Symbolism, not substance, dominated. In Australia, period ratcheting of targets fits this pattern, which is typical for Western democracies. The latest goal — cutting emissions by 62%-70% below 2005 levels by 2035 — may prove overly ambitious. Emissions are currently about 28% below 2005 levels, with only modest progress in recent years (a decline of roughly 1.4% over the past year, and little change relative to three years ago). Unsurprisingly, critical assessments have followed. Hussein Dia, professor of transport technology and sustainability, argues that meeting the national target would require rapid, economy-wide transformation. He emphasises transport — Australia’s third-largest and fastest-growing source of emissions — as pivotal and persistently hard to decarbonise. Australia’s track record on carbon capture remains weak, and shifting heavy road freight to hydrogen appears inefficient relative to battery-electric options given current technologies and energy-efficiency differentials. Even where technologies are viable, the political economy is contested: prospective winners and losers shape the terrain.

2. Beneficiaries in politics. Politicians who championed climate policy early gained moral authority and media dominance. Criticism was often dismissed as immoral or “anti-science”, even though it was clear from the start that climate protection could only work globally, not merely nationally. At the same time, subsidies and levies expanded government revenue and offered room for patronage. Climate protection became a platform for redistribution and client politics.

3. New sources of money. Early climate measures and promises created immediate business opportunities. It is estimated that the electricity sector would require an estimated A$142 billion in capital investment to cover the essential electricity infrastructure by 2050. Subsidies for wind and solar, along with government contracts, fuelled new industries that profited from the money. Other companies thrived on selling “sustainable” products, consulting and certification services. Australia’s multibillion-dollar renewable energy subsidies have produced fortunes for a few, while leaving ordinary households with constantly mounting bills.

4. Bureaucracy loves regulation. Each new climate initiative generated tasks for departments, agencies, and regulators. As mandates and compliance regimes multiplied, Australia’s dual layers of Commonwealth and state authority made duplication and jurisdictional overlap more likely, driving up administrative complexity and costs.

5. Scapegoating. Climate change provided a convenient excuse for national policy failures. In developing nations, poverty could be blamed on global warming rather than corruption or poor governance. In industrialised countries, infrastructure shortcomings and poor preparation for natural disasters were often justified as consequences of a changing climate. Following floods or bushfires, leaders often face pressure to “do something,” a classic action bias in behavioural economics, and the attribution question — “was this climate change?” — can crowd out harder discussions about planning, land use and hazard management. In Australia, national leaders also faced backlash during the 2019 bushfire crisis for declining to engage substantively with climate questions. Globally, climate change can function as an easy scapegoat precisely because the systemic challenges in planning, land use and risk management are less visible, harder to narrate and slower to fix.

6. Passing on costs. Climate-related regulations introduced over time raised costs for companies, but because their competitors nationally and in several Western countries faced the same or similar regulations, those costs were passed on to consumers. In some cases, firms even profited. Europe’s emissions trading system, with free allocations of permits, allowed certain industries to earn windfalls. In Australia, the Safeguard Mechanism (from 2016) and renewable obligations can produce analogous dynamics, where consumers shoulder the costs and industries find ways to profit.

The turn: Why climate policy is losing steam

Now, however, the underlying economic logic is reasserting itself: genuine climate protection to reduce global warming would require effective global cooperation. But, this global cooperation has failed to materialise in practice, even though many climate treaties have been signed and numerous climate conferences have been held. After years of political grandstanding, ambitious policy targets, and vast amounts of subsidies, the climate issue is now losing its appeal. Six developments explain why “peak climate policy” has likely already passed.

1. The return to cost-benefit realism. More than 30 years after the Kyoto Protocol, the politically set climate targets are drawing nearer, and the costs of compliance are rising rapidly. Moralising slogans are giving way to more sober cost-benefit analysis. Many citizens are noticing how inefficient and expensive past strategies have been and how little they have contributed to slowing climate change.

2. Competition from other pressing issues. As the climate discourse loses its “monopoly” in public discourse, other priorities take centre stage: aging populations, pension security, and defence spending in an unstable geopolitical world. The fact is: A dollar cannot be spent twice. In Australia, billions for renewable subsidies will compete with other funding, such as defence, in a shifting Indo-Pacific security environment. The war in Ukraine has quickly shifted political and public opinion to the view that defence is, in the short run, a larger priority than climate change. Worldwide, the climate-adaptation and mitigation policies have substantially dropped since 2023.

3. Everything is relative. Climate damages can look frightening in absolute terms. But relative to growing economic output, they are relatively modest. Sound economic policy that generates decent growth rates has the potential to offset much of the negative impact of climate change. Recent cross-country evidence (147 countries over more than two decades) published in Humanities and Social Sciences Communications (Nature portfolio) reports an environmental-Kuznets-type pattern: as incomes rise, environmental pressures tend to intensify initially and then diminish. This does not trivialise severe local impacts or distributional inequities; it underscores that growth, technological progress and strong institutions expand adaptive capacity, even as targeted support is needed for the most exposed communities.

4. A change of perspective. Knowledge about climate change and climate science has advanced. People recognise that the 1.5°C “target” of the Paris Agreement is unrealistic; in fact, it has always been unrealistic from a socio-economic perspective. Similarly, the reference point against which global warming is measured, namely pre-industrial temperatures, is more symbolic than practical. They also understand that today’s especially rich societies have far greater capacity to cope with change than in 1850.

5. Adaptation instead of prevention. Since large-scale global emissions cuts remain unlikely in the near future, adaptation is moving to the forefront of the debate. Unlike distant promises of prevention, adaptation delivers immediate, tangible benefits. Investments in infrastructure, cooling technologies, water management, and urban design are visible, practical, and often cost-effective. In Australia, measures such as risk-appropriate zoning, fuel management, and improved land use likely deliver greater near-term payoff than symbolic targets. Likewise, air conditioning — long treated as almost taboo in parts of Europe, such as Germany — is increasingly recognised as a straightforward way to reduce heat stress. Americans, of course, have understood this for decades.

6. Climate technologies. New approaches, such as carbon removal or geo-engineering (e.g., rock weathering), are drawing growing attention. Their complexity brings “known unknowns,” such as potential effects on the global water cycle and other Earth-system feedbacks, but support for model-based research and robust governance frameworks is increasing, and complex-systems modelling will improve over time. Politically, the prospect of technological breakthroughs can be attractive because it signals progress without immediate economy-wide sacrifices, which in turn can dampen appetite for conventional mitigation focused on emissions cuts. or Australia, with strong research capacity, these technologies may represent an opportunity — provided they are pursued with rigorous evaluation, transparent risk management and international coordination.

Toward rational policy

Thus, global climate protection, until recently cast as humanity’s defining task, is increasingly giving way to approaches that are more realistic, tangible, and enforceable. The key question is whether a better economic design is available.

The answer is yes: through efficient cost transparency. Every country could adopt a universal CO₂ price. Such a mechanism would create the right incentives for producers and consumers without relying on subsidies, mandates, or complex regulations. The revenues should be fully returned to citizens — for example, via tax reductions on labour or consumption. This approach would be more efficient and more socially acceptable. The burden of a universal carbon price would be far lower than today’s labyrinth of subsidies and levies. Internationally, a simple and universal mechanism offers the best chance for effective cooperation.

Yet a CO₂ price that displaces subsidies and regulations deprives politicians, bureaucrats, and favoured industries of their privileges. The welfare-enhancing path remains blocked — not by economic logic, but by political incentives.

A mature approach

Climate change is real. But the politics of climate change — often marked by apocalyptic rhetoric, moral posturing, and costly symbolism — appears to have peaked. The experiences show both zeal and flaws: contested projections, generous subsidies, and rising household costs. Around the world, voters are beginning to ask harder questions, weighing real trade-offs, and prioritising issues closer to home.

What lies ahead is not the end of climate policy, but its transformation: fewer exaggerations and grand promises, more emphasis on adaptation and proven technologies, and potentially a shift toward economic and behavioural rationality via transparent, economy-wide pricing of emissions. Welcoming this shift is not cynicism; it is policy maturity — the recognition that effective climate action is less about headlines and more about solving problems efficiently, transparently and fairly.

Develop, customize, operate, and maintain a variety of decision-support tools supporting market and economic analysis of energy efficiency, distributed energy resources (solar/storage/EVs), demand response, and related technologies.

Manage small teams of consultants that develop model inputs, providing overall coordination, collaboration, quality control, and schedule/budget management

Interact with clients and other stakeholders to present (written and oral) model methodology, inputs, assumptions, and results/insights.

Collaborate with internal teams to ensure that material aspects of technologies and markets are captured in existing or new models.

A minimum of 6+ years’ experience in energy-efficiency or a related field.

2+ years of project management or team lead experience.

Proven success in developing complex analytical tools to facilitate decision support.

Experience developing, customizing, operating, or maintaining analytical tools involving consumer adoption theory (e.g., logit market share modeling), System Dynamics (stock/flow modeling), or economic analysis (e.g., benefit/cost testing) in the energy field. Exceptional attention to detail and ability to provide quality control of all model inputs and outputs, with proven ability to ensure model results are defensible and will withstand scrutiny by interested parties.

Detail oriented with the ability to multi-task while consistently meeting deadlines with accuracy and within budget.

Excellent verbal and written communication skills.

Interest in sustainability and passionate about making a meaningful impact on the environment.

Preferred skills, education and experience

Master's degree in business, energy, engineering, or related field of study.

Experience developing analytical tools in Analytica, Excel, R, Python, or similar modeling frameworks. Strong preference will be given to those with prior experience with Analytica (www.analytica.com), though qualified candidates will have the aptitude and interest to develop these skills through on-the-job training.

Expertise in linear programming and nonlinear optimization.

Expertise in System Dynamics, including Bass diffusion and other constructs.

Expertise in random utility theory for consumer choice.

Expertise in the standard energy efficiency and other demand-side technology benefit/cost tests.

Expertise in Monte Carlo simulation.

name: EPA
title: Opponents urge EPA to uphold objection to Asheboro permit | Coastal Review
description:
“Frankly I’m embarrassed that Asheboro is polluting the drinking water of as many as 900,000 people who live downstream from us,” longtime Asheboro resident Susie Scott said.
“1,4-dioxane is a synthetic, highly mobile compound that resists natural degradation and conventional water treatment.
Once it enters our watershed, it is persistent and travels far downstream, all the way to our drinking water intakes.
Removing 1,4-dioxane from our drinking water requires advanced and very costly treatment technologies.
The EPA may reaffirm its objection to the permit, require that the state modify the permit, or withdraw its objection of the permit.
text:
North Carolinians from cities, towns and communities throughout the Cape Fear River Basin urged the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to uphold its objection to a municipal wastewater treatment plant’s proposed permit that excludes an effluent discharge limit for 1,4-dioxane into their drinking water sources.

One after another, speakers at a public hearing the EPA hosted last Wednesday night asked the agency to force the state to reissue a permit that will limit discharges of the likely human carcinogen into surface waters that flow into tributaries of the Haw and Deep rivers, which converge to form the Cape Fear River.

Residents from Wilmington northwest to Fayetteville, Sanford, Pittsboro, Siler City, and Asheboro joined representatives of environmental organizations and downstream public water utilities at the hearing at Randolph Community College in Asheboro, the very city that fought to get 1,4-dioxane limits removed from its permit.

“Frankly I’m embarrassed that Asheboro is polluting the drinking water of as many as 900,000 people who live downstream from us,” longtime Asheboro resident Susie Scott said. “The solution, to me, seems simple. Our city should hold the companies producing this pollution to account and insist that they clean up their waste before we accept it into our treatment plant. People living downstream from us deserve safe drinking water.”

In August 2023, the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality’s Division of Water Resources issued Asheboro a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System, or NPDES, permit limiting the city water treatment plant’s release of 1,4-dioxane.

The city sued, challenging the state’s power to include a water quality standard for the clear, odorless chemical solvent used in manufacturing processes.

In September 2024, the Chief Administrative Law Judge for North Carolina at the time, Donald van der Vaart, ruled in the city’s favor and revoked permit limits of 1,4-dioxane.

In his ruling, van der Vaart said that DEQ officials did not follow the letter of the law written in state statutes when they calculated discharge limits and established an enforceable water quality standard for 1,4-dixoane. He also noted anticipated high costs associated with monitoring and treatment of the chemical compound.

DEQ’s appeal of that ruling is pending in Wake County Superior Court.

Costs to treat 1,4-dioxane will fall on the backs of downstream water utilities customers if the pollutant is not controlled at the source, Cape Fear Public Utility Authority Executive Director Kenneth Waldroup said.

“The presence of 1,4-dioxane in our source water is just the latest example of how gaps in regulation can lead downstream communities exposed to risk,” he said. “1,4-dioxane is a synthetic, highly mobile compound that resists natural degradation and conventional water treatment. Once it enters our watershed, it is persistent and travels far downstream, all the way to our drinking water intakes. Removing 1,4-dioxane from our drinking water requires advanced and very costly treatment technologies. We’re talking millions of dollars in systems and additional millions in operations costs over a period of time.”

Waldroup said DEQ “took appropriate action” when it included 1,4-dioxane limits in Asheboro’s NPDES permit, but that the state Office of Administrative Hearings “inappropriately and inaccurately invalidated that move.”

“EPA is obligated to assume permitting authority if the state fails to comply with federal permits, and EPA must require the state of North Carolina to address this pollutant and protect 900,000 downstream users,” he said.

Public water utilities, including CFPUA, and businesses downstream of Asheboro’s wastewater treatment plant were notified by DEQ last January that the plant had discharged substantially high concentrations of 1,4-dioxane into Hasketts Creek, which empties into the Deep River.

Misty Manning, Fayetteville Public Works Commission’s chief operations officer for water resources, recalled to EPA officials last week of the Jan. 24 sampling results reported by the state and Asheboro.

“Asheboro’s own sampling result from that day was 3,520 parts per billion. This is more than 10 times higher than EPA’s calculation of what Asheboro’s discharge should be to protect public health at 22 parts per billion. Without enforceable limits, the city of Asheboro’s pretreatment program has yet to be successful in limiting 1,4-dioxane discharges to levels that meet water quality goals for a pollutant with a reasonable potential to cause or contribute to an excursion above state water quality standards,” Manning said.

She was one of several speakers at the hearing to point out that other municipalities in the state have successfully reduced 1,4-dioxane discharges through industrial pretreatment processes without bearing economic hardship.

“And Asheboro has the responsibility to do likewise, using its permitted authority over their local industrial users,” Manning said. “Downstream communities should not bear the financial burden of treating and removing pollutants introduced by unchecked upstream discharges.”

Last June, the Southern Environmental Law Center filed a lawsuit on behalf of Cape Fear River Watch and Haw River Assembly against Asheboro and the city’s industrial customer StarPet Inc., to stop their discharges of 1,4-dioxane into the Cape Fear River basin.

“As part of its antiregulatory fight, Asheboro has raised the absurd argument that it should not be the one that has to pay to control the cancer-causing pollution that it dumps upstream of drinking water supplies,” SELC attorney Hannah Nelson said. “I want to be clear. Asheboro could stop this pollution today by requiring its industries to treat for 1,4-dioxane, but it has chosen not to. In making that choice, Asheboro forces us, the families, the drinking water utilities, the local businesses, the schools, all of those who live downstream of the city, choose us to have to pay for their pollution.”

Stephen Bell, an attorney with Cranfill Sumer law firm’s Wilmington office and outside counsel for Asheboro, said that the city he represents believes steps DEQ took in implementing the August 2023 permit “set dangerous precedent with far-reaching implications.”

“Asheboro is not asking for no water regulation. They’re asking for regulation in accordance with the state law. As it stands today, based upon the court’s ruling, there is no water quality standard for 1,4-dioxane. The courts, our environmental rulemaking agency, they’re currently addressing this issue of limits for 1,4-dioxane and the EPA should respect that state-level process,” he said.

Once everyone at the hearing who signed up to speak addressed EPA officials, a member of the audience asked when the agency expects to make a final determination on the permit. The EPA may reaffirm its objection to the permit, require that the state modify the permit, or withdraw its objection of the permit.

Paul Schwartz, associate regional counsel in the Water Law Office at EPA’s Atlanta region office, said there is no statutory or regulatory timeline in which the agency must decide.

“In terms of specifying a date, certain that it would be done by, I don’t think we can do that,” he said. “And it doesn’t make it any easier that we’re operating during a period of government shutdown. But I think we want to give it immediate attention and focus on it so it doesn’t drag on too long.”

If the EPA decides to reaffirm its objection or require the permit to be modified, DEQ will have 30 days to submit a revised draft permit to the agency. If DEQ does not do that, the EPA will become the permitting authority.

The EPA is accepting public comments through Oct. 31 via email to R4NPDESComments@epa.gov or by mail to US EPA, NPDES Permitting Section, Water Division, 61 Forsyth Street, SW, Atlanta, GA 30303-8960.

title: Environment: What's Up in GENeva | 27 October – 2 November 2025
description:

→ The session takes place on 27 October 2025, 15:00–16:00 CET at Palais des Nations, Room XVI and online.
Geneva Forum 2025 | Held every year in December, the Geneva Forum brings together international thematic conferences structured around a high-level interactive workshop.
Geneva International Film Festival | From 31 October to 9 November 2025 | Various locations Founded in 1995, the Geneva International Film Festival (GIFF) is one of the oldest film festivals.
text:
The Geneva Environment Network’s weekly newsletter includes the latest information on the global environmental agenda, main events, job vacancies, as well as other useful resources and updates. The Geneva Environment Network is not responsible for the content of any linked site or any link contained in a linked site. Stay tuned and follow us on X (Twitter), Facebook, LinkedIn, Instagram, Bluesky, and Youtube, or visit our website regularly for additional updates.

Image of the week | A flavorful parallel event to the 16th session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development featured renowned chocolatier Pierre Marcolini, who highlighted a new wave of artisans championing transparency, fairness, and quality through direct collaboration with cacao producers. The event “Changemakers for Sustainable Trade — Advancing circular and biodiversity-based economies” underscored the ethical and economic imperative of improving market access for sustainable actors, shedding light on and upscaling changemakers’ work. → Explore how UNCTAD’s BioTrade initiative and the Sustainable Manufacturing and Environmental Pollution (SMEP) programme support policy-driven solutions that advance sustainable trade, empower local changemakers, and foster inclusive economic development.

Momentum Builds Ahead of Minamata COP-6

In the lead-up to the sixth meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Minamata Convention on Mercury (COP-6), which will convene from 3 to 7 November 2025 at the International Conference Centre Geneva (CICG), various events are taking place this week, as Member States and stakeholders gather in Geneva and at CICG for regional meetings and other preparatory activities ahead of the official opening. Public events are being proposed to spotlight the urgency of phasing out mercury and to mobilize greater action toward making mercury history, including this week:

Detoxifying Cosmetics​ and Beauty Ideals – Where policy meets art – Photo Exhibition | 27 October to 16 November 2025 | Quai Gustave-Ador

The photo exhibition “Humanæ” of Angelica Dass will be on display on the shores of Lake Geneva, Quai Gustave-Ador, starting this week. Through powerful portraits that celebrate the true spectrum of human skin tones, the exhibition challenges stereotypes and narrow beauty ideals. It reinforces the important message: mercury has no place in cosmetics, calling for beauty standards that honour uniqueness and diversity — free from toxic chemicals. The activity is organized under the auspices of the UNEP Global Mercury Partnership.

From Science to Action: Protecting the Amazon from Mercury Pollution | 2 November, 17:30 to 20:00 CET | CICG, Room

To amplify the human stories behind mercury pollution and to bring hope, science, and meaningful dialogue to the forefront of the COP-6 agenda, the Secretariat, in coordination with the Geneva Environment Network, is organizing a special event From Science to Action: Protecting the Amazon from Mercury Pollution featuring globally recognized voices in nature conservation, policy, and science. The event will highlight the work of Fernando Trujillo, conservation scientist and National Geographic Rolex Explorer of the Year, who will share insights from decades of research and his advocacy against mercury pollution. Aileen Mioko Smith, Executive Director of Green Action in Japan and co-author of Minamata with photographer W. Eugene Smith, will connect the legacy of Minamata disease to current challenges in the Amazon and introduce the COP-6 photo exhibit Minamata: Photographer’s Eye Project. The dialogue will be followed by a screening of Amazon, the New Minamata? film. The documentary reveals how mercury contamination threatens the inhabitants of Amazonia with the shadow of the Minamata Disease, as it follows the saga of the Munduruku people to contain the destructive impact of gold mining in their ancestral territory. → To attend this event taking place at the CICG on 2 November 2025 from 17:30 to 20:00 CET, kindly register on Eventbrite. To access the venue, please bring a valid identification document.

Other key moments this week include:

Minamata Convention on Mercury Press Conference | 27 October 2025, 10:30 CET | UNOG Press Room & UNWeb TV

Secretariat Briefing on Financial Resources and Mechanism | 2 November, 13:00 to 14:00 CET | CICG

Regional Meetings | 2 November, 14:30 to 17:30 CET | CICG

Youth Forum | 2 November | CICG

→ For further information to prepare for Minamata COP-6 and what you can join also if you are not accredited, consult our update Towards the Sixth Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Minamata Convention on Mercury (COP-6) and rewatch the session and read the summary of the Briefing on the 6th Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Minamata Convention on Mercury held on 2 October 2025.

The Secretariat of the Minamata Convention on Mercury is seeking interns already contracted by the United Nations interested in contributing to this UN environmental conference and gaining hands-on experience in multilateral processes. Interns will support registration and plenary operations. Tasks begin Saturday afternoon, 1 November, with morning and afternoon shifts throughout the week. Interested? Contact mea-minamatasecretariat@un.org for details.

Preparations for the World Wildlife Conference | CITES COP-20

In the run-up to the 20th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) — known as the World Wildlife Conference — a preparatory briefing will take place this week. The Convention aims to ensure that all international trade in CITES-listed species is sustainable, legal and traceable — aligned with the long-term conservation of species. CITES plays an important part in halting biodiversity loss, ensuring its sustainable use, and achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework.

The main conference is scheduled to convene in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, from 24 November to 5 December 2025, where nearly 3,000 participants, including government officials, subject-matter experts, and representatives from local, national, and international intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations engaged in species conservation and the management of wild fauna and flora are expected. Parties at CoP20 will discuss a total 114 agenda items, including 149 working documents and 51 amendment proposals. Whenever the Conference does not reach consensus on a given matter, the decision may be put to a vote. Decisions taken by Parties will come into force 90 days after the end of the meeting unless agreed otherwise. → Register to join the briefing aiming at giving an overview on the content of the negotiations, in person or online at the International Environment House I, on Wednesday 29 October, at 10.30 CET.

Climate Actions Updates Towards COP-30

Climate change remains high on the global agenda as we approach the UN Climate Change Conference COP30 in Belém, with key scientific reports and findings to guide negotiators, body meetings, conferences and preparatory meetings, building momentum ahead of COP30.

New reports include:

State of Climate Action 2025 | Systems Change Lab | 22 October 2025

This report by the Bezos Earth Fund, Climate Analytics, the Climate High-Level Champions, ClimateWorks Foundation and World Resources Institute, under Systems Change Lab, outlines a roadmap for closing the global gap in climate action to help keep the Paris Agreement 1.5°C goal within reach. It warns that progress remains too slow and urges faster action on emissions cuts, carbon removal, and climate finance.

An Eye on Methane: From Measurement to Momentum | UNEP | 22 October 2025

UNEP’s International Methane Emissions Observatory (IMEO) annual report finds that data-driven solutions to rapidly target methane action are available – but progress to scale action must accelerate across governments and companies. → UNEP press release

2025 Climate Technology Progress Report (CTPR): ‘Advancing biobased technologies in the bioeconomy’ | UNEP | 23 October 2025

The report examines how advancing the climate and nature agenda through the integration of technology and sustainable biobased solutions can offer a comprehensive and cost-effective pathway to achieving both objectives simultaneously. It is intended as a resource for policymakers, practitioners, and stakeholders seeking to advance integrated, effective, and equitable climate and nature action in the lead-up to COP 30 and beyond.

UNEP’s 2025 Adaptation Gap Report: Running on Empty will be released on 29 October 2025.

UNEP’s Emissions Gap Report 2025: Off target will be released in the upcoming weeks.

Events taking place this week include:

The twelfth session of the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development (EMRTD) is taking place from 27 to 29 October 2025, to discuss current challenges that have an impact on the realization of the right to development after nearly 40 years after adoption of the UN Declaration on the Right to Development. In this session, the thematic study, “Climate finance: vulnerability and responsibility” (A/HRC/EMRTD/12/CRP.2), will be presented and discussed, alongside a panel discussion that aims to generate actionable recommendations for climate finance mechanisms to support the right to development, especially through transparent and equitable carbon markets. → The session takes place on 27 October 2025, 15:00–16:00 CET at Palais des Nations, Room XVI and online.

Advisory opinions on climate change are also being tackled in various webinars this week:

International Court of Justice (ICJ) Advisory Opinion on Climate Change Obligations and Its Implications for Investment Policy-making | IISD | 29 October 2025 | 14:00 – 15:30 CET | Zoom

This webinar will explore what the ICJ’s findings mean for the future of investment treaty reform, how the opinion might influence investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) cases, and what concrete steps investment policy-makers should consider to align their international investment agreements with states’ climate obligations.

From Opinion to Action: How to Use the Inter-American Advisory Opinion on Climate | AIDA & CIEL | 29 October 2025 | 16:00 – 17:30 CET | Zoom

This online event will mark the launch of “Climate Justice and Human Rights: Legal Standards and Tools from the Inter-American Court’s Advisory Opinion 32/25,” co-authored by more than 20 organizations and experts.

Global Citizen Festival Amazônia | On 1 November, Global Citizen is hosting the Global Citizen Festival: Amazonia to spotlight Indigenous voices, catalyze public and policymaker attention, and direct support to secure at least USD 1 billion to protect and restore the Amazon and strengthen land rights and protections for Indigenous steward communities. Locally, tickets are being earned via civic engagement by Pará residents, ensuring grassroots participation and accountability. The festival aims to magnify the campaign’s reach both in Brazil and globally. → Watch online from 23:00 CET. For any questions and queries, please contact: ruben.hasbun@globalcitizen.org

Ahead of COP30, the Community of Practice on Environment, Climate, Conflict, and Peace — a community that aims to strengthen networking and community building on environmental peacebuilding, conflict-sensitive conservation, climate security, and other related topics — is holding various meetings this week that aims to advance climate action and peacebuilding. → Consult the list of activities.

Additional news include:

High stakes and high flavour: Indigenous chef brings Amazonian soul to COP30 | UN News | 26 October 2025

Rich countries are breaking their 1.5°C obligation: CAN study finds no credible commitments to fossil phase-out, finance, or Just Transition in new Climate Plans. | CAN | 24 October 2025

Without adaptation, climate change becomes a multiplier of poverty, says COP30 President in new letter | COP30 Presidency | 23 October 2025

Climate science and early warnings key to saving lives | UN News | 22 October 2025

The Verdict Is In: To Comply with the Law, COP30 Must Deliver | CIEL | 22 October 2025

The bioeconomy at COP30: putting people, planet and profit in harmony | Nature Positive | 20 October 2025

What to Expect at COP 30 | IISD ENB | 20 October 2025

Celebrating the First International Day of the Deep Seabed

In a landmark decision in July 2025, the 30th session of the International Seabed Authority (ISA) Assembly designated 1 November as the International Day of the Deep Seabed, following a proposal by Fiji, Jamaica, Malta and Singapore. The annual observance aims to deepen global understanding of the deep seabed and its resources, while advancing international cooperation for their sustainable management. 🪼

Safeguarding the deep seabed from potentially harmful activities such deep-sea mining is a growing priority for organizations and experts in Geneva, given its critical role at the nexus of environmental protection, resource governance, and human rights. Echoing ISA Secretary-General Leticia Carvalho’s call that “The Deep Sea Needs Rules,” various events were convened in Geneva this year to spotlight the urgent need for regulatory frameworks and international cooperation. → Learn more on the importance of deep-sea and how Geneva serves as a global hub for shaping policy, advancing research, and promoting human rights in the governance of the deep sea, including deep-sea mining.

Outcomes of Recent Multilateral Meetings Relevant for the Environment

Last week, multilateralism was revived with key outcomes achieved at various intergovernmental decision-making meetings held in Geneva:

The Extraordinary Session of the World Meteorological Congress was held to accelerate and expand the global Early Warnings for All (EW4All) initiative, along with other urgent strategic priorities that cannot wait until the next regular Congress in 2027. At the session:

WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo launched a Call to Action on Accelerating the Implementation of the Early Warnings for All Initiative and a new report Early Warnings for All in Focus: Hazard Monitoring and Forecasting, tracking global progress and gaps in the detection, monitoring, forecasting and warning across the hydrometeorological value chain, including for hazards such as tropical storms, floods, sand and dust storms and extreme heat. → WMO Press Release

WMO, together with the Global Water Partnership (GWP), officially launched the Community of Practice (CoP) on Flood Forecasting , a collaborative space for professionals working on flood forecasting, warning, and early action. It strengthens flood early warning systems and helps deliver timely, actionable information to people at risk. → Join the CoP

WMO adopted the first WMO Youth Action Plan, marking a structured approach to integrating youth perspectives into its work and empowering the next generation of leaders. Immediate priorities include establishing a WMO Youth Network, expanding training opportunities and mentorships, and amplifying youth-led storytelling and communication initiatives.

The World Meteorological Congress endorsed actions to promote Artificial Intelligence for forecasts and warnings. Congress approved a new set of technical regulations concerning early warning services and issued a “call to all stakeholders” to collaborate on the development of AI/machine learning environmental monitoring and prediction technologies, tools and applications.

WMO’s Executive Council, held back-to-back to the Congress, confirmed a total budget of 138.7 million for the biennium 2026/2027 and agreed to the terms of reference and composition of the task force, which will identify proposals for realignment of WMO’s Strategic and Operating Plans during the 2026–2027 biennium.

The 16th United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD16) gathered 170 delegations from member states, including 80 ministers and vice ministers of trade and economy, leading voices from the private sector and strong participation from developing countries, least developed countries and small island developing states – alongside major economies and key trade actors. It “reaffirmed the centrality of a rules-based, open, transparent and equitable multilateral trading system”, as stated by UNCTAD Secretary-General Rebeca Grynspan in her closing remarks. Key outcomes of the conference include:

Adopted an outcome document called “The Geneva Consensus for a Just and Sustainable Economic Order”, reaffirming the fundamental belief that development must leave no one behind and committing to building a more inclusive global economy.

Hosted the announcement of the Sevilla Forum on Debt, led by Spain and supported by UNCTAD and the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA). It will be a new dialogue hub on debt, bringing together all stakeholders, creditors, borrowers, international financial institutions and academia on debt sustainability, management and innovative solutions. The new forum is one of the outcomes of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development (FfD4) and was launched as an initiative under the Sevilla Platform for Action. These initiatives will complement the Sevilla Commitment, the outcome adopted at the Conference that sets out a roadmap to strengthen development financing.

Find out more at what happened at UNCTAD16 in final Press release

Honoring the Legacy of Sir David Nabarro

It is with great sadness that many around the world mourned the passing of Sir David Nabarro last July. Key tributes included:

Paying tribute to David Nabarro | WHO | 30 July 2025

Saddened by Passing of David Nabarro, Secretary-General Hails Former World Health Organization Special Envoy’s Tireless Advocacy to Create Healthier World | UN SG | 29 July 2025

World News in Brief: Remembering Dr. David Nabarro | UN Geneva | 29 July 2025

Remembering Dr. David Nabarro: Visionary leader in global food security and sustainable development | UN Food Systems Coordination Hub | 27 July 2025

In Loving Memory of Dr David Nabarro (1949–2025) | Scaling Up Nutrition | 26 July 2025

Online Tribute Dr. David Nabarro

To honour the life and legacy of Sir David Nabarro (26 August 1949 – 25 July 2025), former Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations, family, friends, colleagues, and fellow advocates will gather at Maison de la Paix. The memorial will celebrate Sir David’s invaluable contributions to public health, the Sustainable Development Goals, and the mission of the United Nations. The memorial ceremony will take place on Friday, 31 October 2025, from 14:00 – 15:30 CET at Maison de la Paix, Auditorium Ivan Pictet. A light reception will follow the event. Please confirm your participation here.

Upcoming Deadlines | Call for Submissions, Contests, Registrations

With the environment high on the agenda of International Geneva and beyond, international processes, negotiations, and fora regularly call for inputs in preparation for future reports and guidelines or for people to support their process. A dedicated update lists calls for submissions related to the environment. Additional updates also list those related to Human Rights Mechanisms and ongoing contests launched by our partners. Deadlines not to be missed during the coming weeks include:

The Science-Policy Panel on Chemical, Waste and Pollution (ISP-CWP) was established at the Intergovernmental Meeting (IM) in Punta del Este, Uruguay, last June. Member States and non-member observer States of the United Nations that were present at the Intergovernmental Meeting are recognised as founding members of the Panel unless they indicate otherwise. Member States and non-member observer States of the United Nations that were not present at the Intergovernmental Meeting, but are intending to become a member of the Panel, are cordially invited to send an official communication expressing their intent to become a member to the interim secretariat at isp-cwp@un.org. Member States are also invited to nominate a national focal point by 31 October 2025.

The call for nominations for membership of the Executive Board of the UNEP Special Programme, also known as the Chemicals and Waste Management Programme, for the upcoming term of February 2026 to February 2028 was issued on 11 August 2025, with the deadline of 1 November 2025. Nominations for both recipient and donor country members and alternates should be submitted directly to the Special Programme Secretariat (unepchemicalsspecialprogramme@un.org).

The World Wildlife Day 2026 Poster Contest is open, inviting graphic designers to spotlight World Wildlife Day 2026 (WWD2026) theme: “Medicinal and Aromatic Plants: Conserving Health, Heritage and Livelihoods.” The conservation of medicinal and aromatic plants (MAPs) is vital, as they form the foundation of many healthcare systems, support diverse industries and play a crucial role in sustaining ecosystems. The contest invites graphic designers to create posters that align with and spread awareness on the theme. → Learn more about the Poster Contest Guidelines and submit by 2 November 2025.

Upcoming conferences, meetings and for which registration is open include:

The eighth session of the Meeting of the Parties to the Convention on Access to Information, Public Participation in Decision-making and Access to Justice in Environmental Matters (Aarhus Convention), the fifth session of the Meeting of the Parties to the Protocol on Pollutant Release and Transfer Registers (Protocol on PRTRs), their joint High-level Segment and associated meetings will take place from 17 to 21 November 2025 in Palais des Nations, Assembly Hall. The Joint High-level Segment will focus on the role of the Aarhus Convention and its Protocol in advancing public rights to tackle the triple planetary crisis of climate change, biodiversity loss and pollution. → Registration for the meetings is open and highly recommended as soon as possible.

The eleventh session of the Conference of the Parties (COP11) to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC) will take place from 17 to 22 November 2025 at the Geneva International Conference Center, back-to-back with the fourth session of the Meeting of the Parties (MOP4) to the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, to be held on 24-26 November 2025 at the World Health Organization Headquarters. Correspondents wishing to cover COP11 and/or MOP4 need to be accredited by 3 November 2025.

Geneva Forum 2025 | Held every year in December, the Geneva Forum brings together international thematic conferences structured around a high-level interactive workshop. These workshops bring together key players from the scientific, associative, institutional, and civic worlds to exchange ideas, debate, and develop concrete solutions to major contemporary challenges. Key announcements ahead of the Forum include:

Regenerative Tourism as a Driver of Transition | The first day of the Forum will be dedicated to “Regenerative Tourism as a Cross-Cutting Solution for High-Impact Transformation Projects” showcasing how responsible tourism is emerging not as a simple moral niche, but as a powerful cross-cutting lever: capable of aligning humanitarian goals, economic benefits, job creation and impact finance requirements. Regenerative tourism is at the core of International Geneva’s priorities: it breaks down silos (ecology, economy, diplomacy, culture), while generating bankable models recognized by impact finance. In this spirit, the Permanent Mission of Portugal will co-develop the opening of the conference, highlighting the strategic importance of oceans in our planetary oxygen. → Register to attend on 8 December 2025 at Palais des Nations, Room XII

The calls for contributions for the Forum cover a wide range of areas: resilient and regenerative tourism, participatory science, peace and diplomacy, civic innovation, project-based education, responsible entrepreneurship, impact projects, international cooperation, etc. Each session invites researchers, practitioners, educators, project leaders, and decision-makers to submit a contribution: a short presentation, case study, feedback, methodological tool, or active participation in the workshops. The call for propositions is open until 17 November 2025.

Happening Abroad

Sixty-third Session of the IPCC (IPCC-63) | At its 63rd session, taking place from 27 to 30 October 2025 in Lima, Peru, the IPCC will consider the work plan for its Seventh Assessment Report (AR7), including the timelines for production of the three working group reports. Other agenda items will include the outline and workplan for production of the Methodology Report on Carbon Dioxide Removal Technologies and Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage, and the IPCC Trust Fund Programme and budget for the years 2025-2028. → Follow the Earth Negotiations Bulletin live coverage

First Meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Article 8(j) and Other Provisions of the CBD Related to Indigenous Peoples and Local Communities (SB8J-1) | Taking place back-to-back with the Twenty-seventh meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice, SB8J-1, established at COP16 in Cali, will focus on matters of relevance to Indigenous Peoples and local communities, that are within the scope of the Convention and its Protocols. → Follow the Earth Negotiations Bulletin live coverage

61st Session of the International Tropical Timber Council (ITTC-61) | ITTC-61 and sessions of the Associated Committees are taking place from 27 to 31 October 2025 in Panama City, Panama. Delegates will consider a working group report on renegotiating the International Tropical Timber Agreement, while also tackling policy matters, including legality frameworks, forest and timber certification and traceability, and sustainable wood use in domestic markets. → Follow the Earth Negotiations Bulletin live coverage

Enjoying a Green Autumn in Geneva

As nature changes colors and days shorter, we invite you to explore activities to enjoy a Green Autumn in Geneva, including this week:

Enquêtes photographiques genevoises : Zoé Aubry, Gabriela Löffel et Laurence Rasti | From 31 October 2025 | Centre de la Photographie Genève & Bibliothèque de Genève | Espace Ami Lullin

Through the lens of these three Geneva-based photographers, Zoé Aubry, Gabriela Löffel, and Laurence Rasti, the exhibition explores the ramifications of mobility and its direct impact on bodies—those that move, cross borders, or transform.

Table ronde participative : Et si manger local n’était plus un privilège ? | 27 October 2025, 17:00 CET | B.R.E.A.D Collective & la Maison de l’alimentation du territoire de Genève | Maison de l’Avenir

The format chosen for the debate is a fishbowl discussion, the principle of which is simple: the speakers sit in a circle in the middle of the room. An extra chair is left empty, and anyone in the audience who wants to share a question, idea, or comment can come and sit in it to participate in the discussion.

Come and Garden With Us | 29 October 2025 | Conservatoire et jardin botaniques

Daffodils, tulips, snowdrops, and crocuses are all bulb plants. Come learn more about these plants and their unique way of surviving winter. You’ll also have the opportunity to plant something that won’t sprout until spring.

Projection du film reportage “Tchernobyl le monde d’après” | 29 October 2025 | Sortir du nucléaire Suisse romande | Cinélux

Nearly four decades after the nuclear disaster of April 26, 1986, eyewitness accounts are rarely heard and reports are contradictory, ranging from soothing to apocalyptic. The film by Cédric Petitjean and Yves Lenoir gives ample voice to witnesses. The screening will be followed by a discussion with Yves Lenoir. The evening is co-organized with the Association of Doctors for the Environment and Doctors for Social Responsibility PSR-IPPNW.

Conférence : Les minorités comme source de changement – Robin Pittet | 30 October 2025 | ASL | Espace Léman

The influence that minorities can have is often underestimated. However, these groups can sometimes be the catalyst for major societal change and play a key role in resolving issues, as was the case with the rescue of Western Europe’s largest lake in the 1980s.

Geneva International Film Festival | From 31 October to 9 November 2025 | Various locations

Founded in 1995, the Geneva International Film Festival (GIFF) is one of the oldest film festivals. A crossroads of genres and disciplines, a place of experimentation, encounters and celebration, it offers every year for ten days, films, series, interactive installations and virtual reality works to some 35,000 festival-goers.

Politique climatique genevoise : est-on sur la bonne voie ? | 1 November 2025 | À l’Espace, Tiers-Lieu d’Après-Genève | Association Climate Genève

In June 2025, the State Council published an Action Plan 2025-2030 for the Cantonal Climate Plan 2030. What does this plan contain in terms of measures relating to mobility, thermal renovation of buildings, biodiversity, renewable energies, the circular economy, air traffic, social justice, democracy, and participation in climate-related decisions?

Des sangliers dans le viseur | 1 November 2025 | La libellule

The mysterious black beast fuels many fantasies. Is it the fearsome behemoth we imagine, ready to charge at you as soon as it sees you? Come and learn more about this powerful and clever animal.

Fête de la glace | 2 November 2025 | Patinoire des Vernets

The Ice Festival offers a day of discovering various sports practiced on ice. Several introductory sessions and demonstrations of ice sports await you at the Vernets ice rink.

Aux aurores | 2 November 2025 | Naries | Chalet de la Dôle

Wake up early to watch the chamois come down from the mountains. Binoculars and cameras are essential for capturing these unique moments!

Notre Biodiversité | Until 30 November 2025 | Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques

In line with the new Municipal Biodiversity Strategy of the City of Geneva an itinerary through the heart of our garden invites us, through short texts printed on sails, to question ourselves on this burning subject and to reflect on our roles as citizens, public authorities, scientific institutions such as ours and civil society.

Léman : L’éveil d’un peuple | Until 14 December 2025 | Association pour la Sauvegarde du Léman | Espace Léman

Through a wealth of documents, testimonials, objects, and audiovisual archive footage, the exhibition “Léman, l’éveil d’un peuple” traces the decisive action taken by associations, scientists, fishermen, journalists, and institutions that helped turn the tide.

What (Else) to Read Next?

European Parliament seals the deal of first-ever EU law on soils | European Environmental Bureau | 23 October 2025

EU lawmakers listened to citizens and science and rubber stamped the deal on the Soil Monitoring Law, the EU’s first ever law on soil health, after months of negotiations. Despite severe shortcomings of the endorsed text, this is an important milestone towards addressing Europe’s crisis of soil degradation. Its success will depend on impactful implementation.

Following the Smoke: Investigation of Ten U.S. Companies Points to a Hidden Tsunami of e-Waste Exports to Asia | Basel Action Network | 22 October

A new investigative report by BAN documents how a group of large U.S brokers appears to be facilitating what BAN estimates to be a billion-dollar trade in exporting electronic waste to developing countries. Based on trade data, field observations and independent GPS tracking, BAN’s findings indicate that significant volumes of electronics continue to be exported to countries that have prohibited their import and often lack capacity for managing them. As enforcement actions in these countries show, this unwelcome or illegal trade nevertheless thrives and persists, raising urgent ethical, environmental, and legal concerns.

State of Global Air | Health Effects Institute | 22 October 2025

Now in its sixth iteration, the latest State of Global Air report presents information on exposures to outdoor and household air pollution and associated adverse health impacts from a variety of pollutants. Air pollution remains the leading environmental risk factor for death around the world, contributing to 7.9 million deaths in 2023, 86% from noncommunicable diseases.

States must prioritise human rights and planetary health in trade, investment and business regulation | UN Special Rapporteur on right to healthy environment, UN Special Rapporteur on climate change and human rights & UN Special Rapporteur on right to development | 21 October 2025

As Geneva hosts the 16th UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), we urge States to seize this important opportunity to underscore the need to reform international trade and investment law in line with international human rights law.

How microplastic pollution is boosting antimicrobial resistance | GAVI | 17 October 2025

Plastics could play a role in driving the development and transmission of AMR throughout their entire life-cycle, a new report warns. During the extraction of raw materials for the fossil fuel industry – including crude oil, natural gas and coal – biocides are used to prevent bacteria from colonising pipelines and equipment carrying oil or mining fluids. These chemicals may be inadvertently released into the environment, fuelling AMR in spill-affected areas. Exposure of microbes to sub-lethal concentrations of biocides can trigger the emergence of resistance and the sharing of resistance genes within biofilm communities.

UN experts urge binding accountability for agribusiness to safeguard peasants’ rights and global food security | OHCHR | 16 October

In their reports to the UN General Assembly, the Working Group on peasants and rural workers and the Special Rapporteur on the right to food warned that the growing dominance of transnational corporations and industrial agribusiness in global food systems poses an escalating threat to food security, rural livelihoods, and human rights.
